title: Audiofunctions+
text:
Audiofunctions+ is a web application that helps visually impaired students learn mathematical functions through sound. By converting function graphs into audio, you can explore and understand mathematical relationships through hearing.



Explore functions with sound: Move through graphs and hear how functions change
Navigate easily: Use simple keyboard shortcuts to control everything
Work with multiple functions: Define and compare different mathematical expressions
Set landmarks: Mark important points for quick navigation





Open the app and press F to define your first function
Move around using arrow keys or J/L to explore the graph
Turn on sound by pressing P to start hearing the function
Adjust the view with Z for zoom, W A S D to move around

title: Exporting/Importing files
text: Audiofunctions+ allows users to import and export function definitions and settings using JSON files. This feature is particularly useful for sharing configurations or backing up your work.

title: Exporting/Importing files
text:
Exporting JSON
To export the current function definitions and settings to a JSON file, follow these steps:

Open the command palette by pressing ctrl+K (or cmd+K on Mac).
Type “export” and select the “Export as file” option.
A JSON file containing the current configurations will be generated and downloaded to your device.

title: Exporting/Importing files
text:
Importing JSON
To import function definitions and settings from a JSON file, follow these steps:

Open the command palette by pressing ctrl+K (or cmd+K on Mac).
Type “import” and select the “Import from file” option.
Choose the JSON file you wish to import from your device.
The application will read the file and update the function definitions and settings accordingly.

title: Exporting/Importing files
text:
JSON file structure
The JSON file used for importing and exporting configurations contains a list of the defined functions and the graph settings. Below is an example of a JSON file structure:
{
  "functions": [
    {
      "id": "f1",
      "functionName": "Function 1",
      "type": "function",
      "functionDef": "sin(x)",
      "isActive": true,
      "instrument": "clarinet",
      "pointOfInterests": [],
      "landmarks": []
    },
    {
      "id": "f2",
      "functionName": "Function 2",
      "type": "piecewise_function",
      "functionDef": [
        ["x^2", "x <= 0"],
        ["x + 1", " 0 < x"]
      ],
      "isActive": false,
      "instrument": "clarinet",
      "pointOfInterests": [],
      "landmarks": []
    }
  ],
  "graphSettings": {
    "defaultView": [-10, 10, 10, -10],
    "minBoundDifference": 0.1,
    "maxBoundDifference": 100,
    "showGrid": true,
    "showAxes": true,
    "gridColor": "#CCCCCC",
    "restrictionMode": "none"
  }
}
In this example, the JSON file contains two functions: a sine function and a piecewise function. The graphSettings section includes various settings for the graph display, such as the default view boundaries and grid visibility.

title: Exporting/Importing files
text:
Tweaking JSON Files
You can manually edit the JSON file to modify function definitions or graph settings before importing it back into Audiofunctions+. For instance, you can visualize the following “non-graph” function



Plotting two functions simultaneously


example in the following way.
Insert the following date in the edit functions menu:



Editing a non-graph function


Export it to a JSON file as explained above, and then open the JSON file in a text editor. You will see something like this:
{
  "functions": [
    {
      "id": "f1",
      "functionName": "Function 1",
      "type": "piecewise_function",
      "functionDef": [
        ["0", "x<0"],
        ["1/10 x^2", "x>=0"]
      ],
      "isActive": false,
      "instrument": "clarinet",
      "pointOfInterests": [],
      "landmarks": []
    },
    {
      "id": "f2",
      "functionName": "Function 2",
      "type": "piecewise_function",
      "functionDef": [["-1/20 x^2", "x>=0"]],
      "isActive": true,
      "instrument": "clarinet",
      "pointOfInterests": [],
      "landmarks": []
    }
  ],
  "graphSettings": {
    "defaultView": [-10, 10, 10, -10],
    "minBoundDifference": 0.1,
    "maxBoundDifference": 100,
    "showGrid": true,
    "showAxes": true,
    "gridColor": "#CCCCCC",
    "restrictionMode": "none"
  }
}
Set the field isActive of all functions from true, save the file and import it back into Audiofunctions+ as explained above.
When you activate the sonification, you will hear both functions sonified simultaneously.

title: Audiofunctions+
text:
Audiofunctions+ is a web application that helps visually impaired students learn mathematical functions through sound. By converting function graphs into audio, you can explore and understand mathematical relationships through hearing.



Explore functions with sound: Move through graphs and hear how functions change
Navigate easily: Use simple keyboard shortcuts to control everything
Work with multiple functions: Define and compare different mathematical expressions
Set landmarks: Mark important points for quick navigation





Open command palette: Ctrl+K (Cmd+K on Mac)
Basic navigation:

Move cursor: Arrow keys or J/L
Move view: W, A, S, D
Show coordinates: C

Manage functions:

New function: Press F and use function editor
Switch between functions: N or number keys 1-9

Audio controls:

Sonification on/off: P
Play entire function: B
Switch sonification type: I






Take full control of your navigation with these advanced movement options:

Fluid/stepwise movement: Shift+Arrow keys for smooth movement
Zoom/Scale controls: Z and Shift+Z to enlarge/shrink the view around its center
Axis-specific zooming/scaling: X+Z and Shift+X+Z for X-axis, Y+Z and Shift+Y+Z for Y-axis
Center cursor: Ctrl+Z to reorientate the view, that the cursor is in the center
Mouse movement with volume feedback: Move your mouse across the graph to hear function values through volume changes - louder sounds indicate higher values, quieter sounds indicate lower values




Create interactive markers at important points on your functions - landmarks help you quickly navigate to specific coordinates and understand key features of mathematical graphs:

Create/edit landmark: Ctrl+B (Cmd+B on Mac) at desired position
Jump between landmarks: Ctrl+Arrow keys or J and L (Cmd+Arrow keys on Mac)
Jump to specific landmark: Ctrl+Number key (Cmd+Number key on Mac)

title: Sharing & Restriction Modes
text: Audiofunctions+ provides powerful sharing capabilities and restriction modes that allow you to control how others interact with your mathematical functions. Whether you’re an educator preparing materials or a student sharing work, these features give you precise control over the experience.

title: Sharing & Restriction Modes
text:
Sharing Functions

Quick Share
The easiest way to share your functions is through the built-in sharing feature:

Open the command palette by pressing Ctrl+K (or Cmd+K on Mac)
Type “share” and select the “Share” option
Configure your settings (optional) and click “Create Share Link”
Copy and send the generated link to others



Share Options
When sharing, you can customize several aspects:

Restriction Mode: Control what users can do with your shared functions
View Bounds: Set minimum and maximum zoom levels
Advanced Settings: Fine-tune the sharing experience



Alternative Sharing Methods
You can also share functions by:

Saving as file: Export to JSON and share the file directly
Manual sharing: Copy your function definitions for others to input manually

title: Sharing & Restriction Modes
text:
Restriction Modes
Restriction modes give you control over how recipients can interact with your shared functions. There are three levels available:

None (Default)

Full access: Users can modify, edit, and explore everything
Complete functionality: All features are available
Best for: Collaborative work, learning environments where exploration is encouraged



Read Only

View and explore: Users can navigate and hear the functions
No editing: Cannot modify function definitions or add new functions
Limited changes: Can adjust view settings like zoom and position
Best for: Sharing completed work, demonstrations where you want to prevent accidental changes



Full Restriction

Viewing only: Users can only see and hear the predefined functions
No modifications: Cannot edit functions, change settings, or import/export
Fixed experience: Ensures everyone sees exactly what you intended
Best for: Presentations, assessments, situations requiring identical experiences for all users

title: Sharing & Restriction Modes
text:
How Restriction Modes Work
When you share a link with restrictions:

Recipients open the link in their browser
Audiofunctions+ loads with your functions and settings
Interface adapts based on the restriction level you set
Features are hidden/disabled according to the restrictions

title: Sharing & Restriction Modes
text:
Practical Examples

For Educators
"restrictionMode": "read-only"
Share homework solutions where students can explore and understand the functions without accidentally modifying them.


For Presentations
"restrictionMode": "full-restriction"
Ensure your audience sees exactly the same view during a presentation or demonstration.


For Collaboration
"restrictionMode": "none"
Let team members freely edit and build upon your work.

title: Sharing & Restriction Modes
text:
Setting Up Restrictions

Through the Share Dialog

Open command palette (Ctrl+K)
Select “Share”
Choose your Restriction Mode from the dropdown:

None
Read Only

Full Restriction

Configure any additional settings
Create and share your link



Through File Export
When exporting JSON files, you can also set restriction modes:

Open command palette (Ctrl+K)
Select “Export as file”
Set the Restriction Mode in the export settings
Save and share the JSON file

title: Sharing & Restriction Modes
text:
Tips for Effective Sharing

Choose the Right Mode

Use None for collaborative work
Use Read Only for demonstrations where exploration is encouraged
Use Full Restriction for controlled presentations



Test Before Sharing
Always test your shared link to ensure it works as expected and provides the intended experience.


Communicate Clearly
Let recipients know what they can and cannot do with the shared functions to set proper expectations.


Consider Your Audience

Students learning: Read Only often works best
Colleagues collaborating: None gives full flexibility
Public presentations: Full Restriction ensures consistency

title: Sharing & Restriction Modes
text:
Troubleshooting

Link Not Working

Check that the restriction mode is appropriate for your intended use
Ensure the link was generated correctly
Try regenerating the share link



Features Missing
If certain features seem unavailable, check the restriction mode - this is likely intentional based on the sharing settings.


Can’t Edit Functions
This is normal behavior in Read Only and Full Restriction modes. Contact the person who shared the link if you need editing access.

Sharing and restriction modes help you control the mathematical exploration experience while maintaining the accessibility and educational value of Audiofunctions+.

title: Sharing Functions
text: Share your mathematical functions with others and control how they can interact with them.

title: Sharing Functions
text:
How to Share

Press Ctrl+K (or Cmd+K on Mac) to open the command menu
Type “share” and select “Share”
Choose your restriction mode (see below)
Click “Create Share Link”
Copy and send the link to others

title: Sharing Functions
text:
Restriction Modes
None - Full access - Recipients can edit functions and change all settings - Use for: Collaborative work, group projects
Read Only - View and explore only - Recipients can navigate and hear functions but cannot edit them - Can still zoom, move view, and create landmarks - Use for: Sharing homework solutions, demonstrations
Full Restriction - Viewing only - Recipients can only see and hear the exact functions you set up - Cannot change anything - Use for: Presentations, tests, controlled experiences

title: Sharing Functions
text:
Alternative Methods
Export as file: 1. Press Ctrl+K → “Export as file” 2. Choose restriction mode in settings 3. Save and share the JSON file
Manual sharing: Simply tell others your function definitions to type in themselves.

title: Sharing Functions
text:
What Recipients See
When someone opens your shared link: - Your functions load automatically - Interface adapts based on restriction level - Restricted features are hidden or disabled

Tip: Always test your shared link before sending to ensure it works as expected.

title: Sharing Functions
text:
What Gets Shared
When you create a share link, the complete state is saved: - All your function definitions - Current visibility of each function - Current view position and zoom level as standard - Any landmarks you’ve created
This means recipients see exactly what you see when you create the link.
